body:
**Chapter 11**

> 2 **Now I commend you since you have remembered everything of me and are observing the teachings** as I gave them to you.
> 
> 3 Now I want you to know that the head of every man is the Anointed, but the head of woman is man, 4-16 blah blah blah, no long hair on men despite the rest of the bible and no short hair on women, women are pieces of flesh made solely for sex, etc.
> 
> 17 **But I do not commend you on these instructions**, and because of them you meet together for the worse and not the better. First, although you are indeed meeting as an congregation, I hear that there are divisions among you...

17 and onwards only makes sense following immediately after 2, and 3-16 interrupt sharply interrupt. 3-16 has also been said to not match Paul's writing style.

**Chapter 14**

> prophesying stuff...31 **You can prophesy one by one so everyone will learn and be called [and the spirits of prophets are obedient to prophets]**, 32 for God is not of disorder but of peace, 33 as in all the congregations of the holy.
> 
> 34 The women in the congregations are to shut up, for it is not allowed to them to speak, but to be subordinate as the law also says. 35 And if they want to learn something they are to ask their own husbands at home, for it is shameful for a woman to speak in a congregation.
> 
> 36 Or has the word of God come from you? Or has it only come to you? 37 **If anyone thinks they are a prophet or spiritual**, be aware that what I write to you is the commandments of Master.

Yet again, why does a completely unrelated topic come up smack in the middle of another one, without even any transition whatsoever? And notice how "Paul" in verse 34 appeals directly to "the law" for his argument, which he has spent the entire rest of his epistles *discounting*. Plus, there is no known Jewish law for this; it was a law of the Roman Empire.

title: Why 1 Corinthians 11:3-16 and 14:34-35 are NOT authentic

body:
Anything written by Paul is automatically suspect, to be honest - Hebrews is the most theologically sound of the "Pauline" epistles, and it's the one least likely to have been written by him. Peter and James are much more theologically sound.

The disciples told us to emulate Jesus and do as he commanded, Paul told us to worship him and not worry about dressing, eating or acting like he did or like he commanded.

body:
> Anything written by Paul is automatically suspect, to be honest - Hebrews is the most theologically sound of the "Pauline" epistles, and it's the one least likely to have been written by him.

Actually the least likely ones to have been written by Paul are 1 Timothy and Titus, and they are probably the most vile books in the entire bible. Hebrews at least has a small chance of being written by Paul in another language and loosely translated by Luke. In my experience real Paul is legit but he's still only a man, and his letters are so heavily edited by the church fathers that it's basically impossible to know what he really thought.

> Peter and James are much more theologically sound.

1 "Peter" is definitely a forgery repeats exactly same crap they inserted into Paul's epistles:

> 1 Peter 2:13 Submit yourselves for the Lord’s sake to every human authority: whether to the emperor, as the supreme authority, 14 or to governors, who are sent by him to punish those who do wrong and to commend those who do right. 15 For it is God’s will that by doing good you should silence the ignorant talk of foolish people.

> 1 Peter 3:1 Wives, in the same way submit yourselves to your own husbands so that, if any of them do not believe the word, they may be won over without words by the behavior of their wives, 2 when they see the purity and reverence of your lives. 3 Your beauty should not come from outward adornment, such as elaborate hairstyles and the wearing of gold jewelry or fine clothes. 4 Rather, it should be that of your inner self, the unfading beauty of a gentle and quiet spirit, which is of great worth in God’s sight. 5 For this is the way the holy women of the past who put their hope in God used to adorn themselves. They submitted themselves to their own husbands, 6 like Sarah, who obeyed Abraham and called him her lord. You are her daughters if you do what is right and do not give way to fear.
> 
> 7 Husbands, in the same way be considerate as you live with your wives, and treat them with respect as the weaker partner and as heirs with you of the gracious gift of life, so that nothing will hinder your prayers.

This one is a little less certain as it could be considered either turning the other cheek or just making excuses to keep slaves in check:

> 1 Peter 2:18 Slaves, in reverent fear of God submit yourselves to your masters, not only to those who are good and considerate, but also to those who are harsh. 19 For it is commendable if someone bears up under the pain of unjust suffering because they are conscious of God. 20 But how is it to your credit if you receive a beating for doing wrong and endure it? But if you suffer for doing good and you endure it, this is commendable before God.

2 Peter *could* be authentic but it's unlikely and appears to be dependent on Jude.

James is mostly sound, though probably not the work of the actual James (but in this case likely one of his students). There is one part that is suspect however:

> James 2:14 What good is it, my brothers and sisters, if someone claims to have faith but has no deeds? Can such faith save them? 15 Suppose a brother or a sister is without clothes and daily food. 16 If one of you says to them, “Go in peace; keep warm and well fed,” but does nothing about their physical needs, what good is it? 17 In the same way, faith by itself, if it is not accompanied by action, is dead. 18 But someone will say, “You have faith; I have deeds.” Show me your faith without deeds, and I will show you my faith by my deeds. 19 You believe that there is one God. Good! Even the demons believe that—and shudder. 20 You foolish person, do you want evidence that faith without deeds is useless? 21 Was not our father Abraham considered righteous for what he did when he offered his son Isaac on the altar? 22 You see that his faith and his actions were working together, and his faith was made complete by what he did. 23 And the scripture was fulfilled that says, “Abraham believed God, and it was credited to him as righteousness,” and he was called God’s friend. 24 You see that a person is considered righteous by what they do and not by faith alone. 25 In the same way, was not even Rahab the prostitute considered righteous for what she did when she gave lodging to the spies and sent them off in a different direction? 26 As the body without the spirit is dead, so faith without deeds is dead.

Although some have argued that it's about evidence and not requirement.
